text: TITLE CARD: "FIRST QUARTER" then "1981"
An upper middle-class neighborhood, known as the Black Beverly Hills.  Big houses, green grass and Caddies in ev other driveway.  The street is quiet, until --
You wanna be Kareem? CAMERA REVEALS: QUINCY MCCALL, eleven years old, dribblin basketball in front of KELVIN and JAMAL, also eleven.  He sports a fro, a "Clippers" jersey, and a serious swagger.
All his big butt do is stand by the basket.
Shoot, I'll be blocking your stuff.
I'm gonna be like Dr. J.
I'ma be like my Dad.
He ain't a star or nothing.
I don't see none of your sorry daddies in the NBA.

Hey, look, Q. Quincy follows Kelvin's eyes, to a beat-up pair of Conver All-Stars approaching from next door.  Walking in the kic is a YOUNG KID in a T-shirt and Tuff-skins, and a LAKERS pulled low.  A moving van is parked in the driveway. KELVIN (cont'd)
Thought only girls were moving in.
That's what my Moms said.
I hope he can ball.
Bet he's a scrub. The Kid stops at the edge of Quincy's driveway.
Hey.
Hey.
Can I play?
You nice?
Yeah, I'm nice. Quincy looks the Kid up and down, then --

You and Kelvin gainst me and Jamal. Quincy tosses the Kid the ball.  The Kid pulls off the baseball cap.  Brown hair tumbles down, framing a soft br face and bright eyes.  She is MONICA WRIGHT, eleven years old.
Ah man, he is a girl.
Girls can't play no ball.
Ball better than you. Quincy laughs derisively as Monica walks to the top of th driveway.
(whispering)
What a dog. Monica shoots him a glare.
She heard you.

Nuh uh, they could only hear dog whistles. Monica starts to dribble.  Jamal whistles as he walks backwards, guarding her.  She throws up a shot.  IT'S AN AIRBALL.  Quincy and Jamal crack up.  Kelvin rolls his ey Quincy grabs the rebound and shoots.  Swish. QUINCY (cont'd)

One, zip. He rolls the ball to Monica.  She starts dribbling and ag Jamal just backs up with her.  She passes to Kelvin.  Jam and Quincy collapse on him, leaving Monica open under the basket.  Trapped Kelvin has no choice but to pass it back Monica catches the ball and throws up a shot.  It banks o the backboard...AND DROPS THROUGH THE NET.  The boys look her in shock.  Monica tosses the ball back to Quincy.
One, up.
Lucky. Quincy easily dribbles by Kelvin and lays up the ball.  H throws the ball back to Monica. QUINCY (cont'd)
Two, one. Monica dribbles.  Jamal plays her a little tighter.  Moni bounces the ball through his open legs and lays up the ba
Two, up. Quincy can't believe it.  Kelvin cracks up.
Aaah, she dogged you.

Shut up. The game continues, with Quincy and Monica trading basket for their teams.  Quincy grows agitated with Jamal, who i unable to stop her.  The score hits nine, nine. Quincy stands at the top of the driveway, ball in hand.

Point. Quincy dribbles through his legs, then pops an outside sh The ball bounces on the rim...and rolls off. Quincy curses as Monica grabs the rebound and clears the ball.  Jamal moves to guard her, but Quincy shoves him of QUINCY (cont'd)
I got her. Quincy defends.  Monica smiles back at him.
Told you I was nice.  I'm going to be the first girl in the NBA.

I'ma be in the NBA.  You're gonna be my cheerleader. Monica suddenly passes to Kelvin, sprints for the basket. Quincy stumbles, giving her a step.  Kelvin throws it bac Quincy knows he's beat as Monica goes for the winning lay In desperation, he swings at her for the hard foul, shovi her off balance.

head_text.subj: THE BALL FLIES FROM HER HAND AS SHE CRASHES TO THE GROUND
FACE-FIRST. SHE GRABS HER CHEEK. BLOOD SLIPS THROUGH HE

text: The boys stand frozen.  Quincy stares down at her, his ey wide with fear...and regret.
Monica leans over the sink as her mother, CAMILLE, 36, wi the blood from her face with a washcloth.
Eeew. Her sister, LENA, 14, leans in the doorway, making a face She is a mirror of their mother, with relaxed hair and painted nails. Her father, NATHAN, 39, moves behind Lena, holding a box.
How are you feeling, munchkin? Monica nods.  He smiles. NATHAN (cont'd)
Yeah, you're through.
She needs to stop running around like a little boy.
She's alright.
How is she alright looking the way she does?
Camille, she'll be fine. He gives Monica a wink, crosses away.  Monica pulls the washcloth away from her Mom and starts wiping the blood herself.

I'll get some ice. She exits.  Lena shakes her head, follows. Monica pulls the washcloth from her face and stares into mirror.  TORN SKIN SURROUNDS A SMALL DEEP GASH IN HER CHE Seeing her latest battle scar, there's only one thing lef for this little girl to do.  She smiles.

Quincy sits at the kitchen table, writing "I AM SORRY" in block letters across a homemade card.  His face is tight concentration as he tries to write in a straight line. At the counter, his mom, NONA, moves a cake from its stor box to a cake dish.  She is 30, beautiful, with effort. smooths the frosting with a spoon. ZEKE, 32, with the height and ego of an NBA ballplayer, enters.  He laughs.
Girl, who you trying to fool? Quincy looks up, smiles.  He quickly grabs a piece of crumpled paper, and tosses it to Zeke.
Alley-oop, Dad. Nona intercepts his pass.
Boy... She points him back to his card.  Quincy scowls, starts writing again.  Nona scoops some frosting on her finger, holds it up. NONA (cont'd)
New neighbors. Zeke wraps his lips around her finger, sucks the frosting off.

See, Quincy, this is how your Moms caught me, with the old fake and bake.  Had me thinking I was getting a sister who could burn. Nona laughs, pulls him down for a kiss.  Quincy suddenly throws down his pencil in frustration.
I can't do this shit. Zeke and Nona pull away, stare at Quincy in shock.
Boy, what'd I tell you about using that word?
(sighs, then)
"Can't" should never be in a man's vocabulary.
Why not?
Cause when you say can't, you ain't a man.
That's right.
Zeke.
What? (then)
Oh, and, uh, don't say "shit." Nona just shakes her head.
We should head over.
Just you and Quincy, baby.  I got a meeting.
With who?
Business folks.
You just got back from a four game road trip.
Nona, don't start bitching.  I got maybe two years left to play.  I'm just trying to put some things together for us. Zeke grabs his keys. ZEKE (cont'd)
Later, Quincy.
Later, Dad. Zeke exits.  Nona leans against the counter, concerned. QUINCY (cont'd)
Mom?
What?
We still have to go?
(beat)
Yeah.

Camille and Nona stand among the piles of boxes.  Monica Quincy stand at their mothers' sides, stealing glances at each other.  A large bandage covers Monica's cheek.  Moni holds her card, Camille holds the cake.
...we moved back here when Quincy was about five, after Zeke was traded. Neighborhood was a little more mixed back then...
Until the Black family down the street became the Black family next door.
(nods)
Okay? Camille tries to smooth down Monica's unruly hair.  Monic moves her head.
Well, thanks again.  This was really nice of you.
It was the least we could do.  And I love to cook. Quincy looks up at his Mom, surprised.  She quickly hugs face into her stomach.  Camille lights up.
Oh, me too.  I used to cook for my friends' parties and things back in Atlanta.
You're a caterer?
Well, no, but once Nathan gets settled and the girls get a little older, it's definitely something I want to do. (then)
Since you love to cook, maybe it's something we can talk about. Quincy snickers.  Nona quickly changes the subject.
You know, girl, long as I've lived next door, I've never seen the inside of this house.
Really?  Well, come on, then. Camille hands Monica the cake. CAMILLE (cont'd)
Honey, put this in the kitchen.

Help her, Quincy. Camille and Nona head down the hall, leaving Monica and Quincy alone.  The two just stand there. Quincy reaches out, scoops a finger of frosting, and pops in his mouth.  Beat, then Monica takes a bigger scoop.
So...does it hurt?
It's this big hole.  You could almost see bone.
For real?
Uh huh. Quincy is impressed.
So how come you could play basketball?
I just can.
I never knew a girl that could play.
My Mom says she doesn't know where I come from 'cause I act different.
Your Dad play?
He works at a bank.
My Dad plays for the "Clippers."  He says I'ma be a doctor or a lawyer, but I'ma play for them, too.  Same number and everything.
I'm going to be number thirty-two, like Magic.
He's alright, but my Dad can take him.
What was the most points your Daddy ever got in Junior High?
I don't know.  A lot.
One time Magic scored forty-eight points, and they only had six minute quarters and he sat out the whole fourth.
You do act different.
I don't care.
Well, if anybody bothers you, you could just tell me cause I run this street.
I'd just tell my sister, Lena.
She don't know how to box, I bet.  My dad showed me how to fight like Ali. He shows off a flurry of punches.
So, I know karate from "Almighty Isis." Monica puts the cake down on a box, does a couple of kick and hand movements.  Quincy is impressed.
Bet you can't do this though. Quincy does a jump kick.  Monica does the same. QUINCY (cont'd)

Okay, how bout this? Quincy takes a couple steps back, then does a cartwheel. looks great, until he crashes into the box with the cake. The cake falls onto his head and shoulder. Monica doubles over, laughing.  Quincy is embarrassed. Camille and Nona rush back into the living room.
Monica, what did you do?
Nothing.
(to Nona)
Oh, all that work.
It's...it's okay.  Can I get a towel? Camille quickly crosses into the kitchen.  Quincy stares the floor.
Sorry. Nona bends down, whispers in his ear.
No.  Good boy.
Monica sits between Lena's legs, grimacing, as Lena works comb through her freshly washed, kinky hair.  Monica's he flops like a rag doll.  Her eyes are wet.
Ow! Lena keeps tugging. MONICA (cont'd)
Ow, Lena!!! Monica punches her in the leg.
Ow! Lena yanks Monica's head back as Camille enters, carrying yellow dress on a hanger.  Monica sees it and her face fa
Ah, Mom.
I'm lucky I found it.  Someone put your box of dresses under a pile of rags in the garbage. Monica sulks.  Lena cackles in her ear.  Camille has to laugh. CAMILLE (cont'd)
Child, pick up your lip.
I hate it.
Fine, you don't like this one, which one would you rather wear?
Pants. Camille rubs her temples, then hangs the dress on the doo
(to Lena)
When you're done can you make sure she brushes her teeth?
Are you okay?
I just need to lay down.  I've been running around all day. Just then, Nathan enters.  He holds up two dress shirts a it were a matter of life and death.
Which one for tomorrow?
The blue.
You sure? Camille nods.  Nathan looks at both of them, then: NATHAN (cont'd)
Can you iron both tonight just in case?
(beat)
Okay.
Thanks, sweetheart. He kisses her on the cheek, hands her the two shirts and crosses out.  Monica just watches.  Beat, then Camile tur back to her daughters.
The boy next door is riding with you to school so you'll know somebody your first day. (to Lena)
Hurry so she can go to sleep. Monica reacts, surprised.  Camille leaves.  Lena puts the comb back to Monica's hair.  Beat, then:
Make it look nice, kay.

Basketball posters, "Clippers" and USC memorabilia, a basketball globe light. Quincy lays tucked in bed, eyes wide open, listening to h parents MAKING LOVE.  The sounds bring a smile to his fac Quincy climbs out of bed, wearing underwear.  He moves to window, sees Monica through her window directly across fr his.  Her eyes are closed as Lena braids her hair.  Quinc kneels down, rests his arms on the window sill, and watch

Quincy sits atop his BMX bike in front of Monica's house. basketball is tucked under his arm. Monica emerges, walking her banana-seater.  She is lookin cute in her yellow dress and braids tied with ribbons.  A basketball sits in her back basket. Quincy is taken aback, stares at her.
You wanna be my girl? Monica blinks in surprise.  She thinks for a moment.
What do I have to do?
I guess, you know, we play ball and we ride to school together.  And if you get mad at me, I gotta give you flowers.
I don't like flowers.
Oh.
How bout Twinkies?  My mom won't ever buy them.
Kay.
Okay. An awkward beat between the new couple.  Finally --
I think we gotta kiss now.
For how long?
Five seconds. The two glance around, then climb off their bikes and wal the secluded area between their two houses. QUINCY (cont'd)

Ready? Monica nods.  They lean in, eyes wide open, and touch lip Quincy counts to five with his fingers.  They pull away, embarrassed, and walk back to the driveway. Monica lifts her bike from the ground and climbs on. QUINCY (cont'd)
Wait.  Cause you're my girl now you gotta ride my bike.
I want to ride my own bike.
My Dad always drives my Mom.
So?
(impatient)
So that means I have to ride with you. Monica doesn't move. QUINCY (cont'd)
Come on.
I don't have to do what you say.
Man, forget you then, stupid.
You're stupid.  And your Daddy plays for the worst team in the NBA. Quincy's face instantly clouds.
What?
(laughs)
Last time they won, Dr. J. was a nurse.
Shut up! He shoves her, knocking her off her bike. QUINCY (cont'd)
I don't wanna be your boyfriend, you ugly dog! Monica leaps up, her dress now dirty.  She shoves him bac
I don't want to be your girlfriend, big head! They grapple, then fall to the ground swinging...
FOOTAGE.  Men's NCAA Finals.  Michigan State against Indi State.  Magic Johnson against Larry Bird.  Magic drives o Bird, hits a beautiful scoop shot.  He celebrates as he j back down court...
TITLE CARD: "SECOND QUARTER" then "1988"

A snarling Black cougar glares down from a large mural. the court below, a girl's basketball play-off game. The bleachers are almost half-full with a hyped crowd.  I the crowd are Monica's parents.  Her father is excited an vocal.  Her mom reads a book.  Also in the stands, the HE COACH OF THE TENNESSEE LADY VOLS, PAT SUMMIT. A fine-ass BROTHER leans in the doorway, sporting a lette jacket with an embroidered "Q" on the chest.  He gets as attention as the game.  A couple of JUNIOR VARSITY CHEERLEADERS smile his way.

"U", "G", "L", "Y", you ain't got no alibi, you ugly, yeah, yeah, you ugly. "M", "A", "M", "A", how you think you got that way, your Mama, yeah, yeah, your Mama. On the floor, MONICA, dribbles down court.  Just EIGHTEEN her athletic figure has a few curves, but her loose jerse does little to show it off.  Her hair is a mess and her k are dark with bruises.  A small scar is visible on her ch She whips a no-look, around the back pass to a cutting TEAMMATE under the basket, who scores.  The crowd cheers. Monica defends the opposing point guard like a gnat.  She knocks the ball loose and grabs it up.  She goes for a la and the opposing guard steps in front of her.  Monica cra into her, knocking both to the floor. A WHISTLE.
No basket!  Offensive foul, number thirty- two. Monica leaps up.
What?  She wasn't set! The referee ignores her. MONICA (cont'd)
She was still moving! From the sideline, COACH HISERMAN waves frantically.
Monica!  Let it go! Monica stares down the ref as she jogs back on defense. The opposing guard drives the lane and puts up a shot. Monica leaps and blocks it with a taunting scream.  A WHISTLE.
Technical foul!  Number thirty-two. Coach Hiserman slams down his clipboard.  Monica charges referee.  A teammate grabs at her but she pushes her off.
For what?
Taunting.
Taunting?!
Sub!
Man, you suck! The referee whips back around, whistle in mouth.  Coach Hiserman grabs her arm and pulls her off the court.

Sit down and shut up. Monica slams down in a chair, sweat pouring, hands clench Her mom watches from the stands, completely embarrassed. brother in the doorway turns, leaves. Monica looks up at the clock.  SIX MINUTES LEFT IN THE TH QUARTER.

Monica, still benched, sits slumped in her chair, her swe on, her face dry.  She glances up at the clock.  TWENTY SECONDS LEFT IN THE FOURTH QUARTER.  Her team's up by SIX Her teammates dribble out the clock.  The BUZZER SOUNDS a they dance across the floor.  Monica looks up in the stan COACH SUMMIT IS GONE.
Camille, now forty-three, stands at the stove stirring a of gumbo.  Lena, 21, and pretty, stands next to her, hold a handful of plates and silverware.
...and if you want a thicker base, you can cut in a potato or just use a little flour.
But you use potato? Camille nods as they cross into:
At the table, Monica is in mid-conversation with her dad. Camille and Lena start setting the table.
Dad, you have to talk to Coach for me.
And what am I supposed to say to the man?
The coach from Tennessee was there and he has me riding the bench.
You lost your head.
I was just showing emotion.
So that means it's alright for you to act like that?
(to Monica)
What'd you do?
(dismissive)
nothing.
I don't know why I keep hoping you'll grow out of this tomboy thing.
I won't.  I'm a lesbian. Lena chokes on her drink, cracks up.
That's not funny
Well, that's what you think, isn't it? Cause I'd rather wear a jersey than an apron...
Watch your mouth. Nathan quickly jumps in, tries to clean things up.
Monica, I think her point is...maybe it's time to start thinking about other things besides basketball.
(taken aback)
What?
You only have one game left and you haven't been recruited.  Munchkin, I wanted it as bad as you did, but we have to face reality.
The coach from USC is going to be at the championship.
I know.  But chances are...
Chances are there's still a chance. Nathan nods.  She can always soften her dad, but not her

If you'd just listen for once, you'd realize you have a lot more going for yourself.  You're smart, you'd be pretty if you put a comb to your head.  I mean, why walk around with your hair looking like "whodunit"...? As her mom nags on, Monica looks out the window. OUTSIDE, QUINCY and a GIRL lean against a car parked at t curb, slobbing each other down. Just shy of 18, with a magnetic face and muscular body, h a brother who drank his chocolate milk.  HE IS ALSO THE

head_text.subj: BROTHER WHO WAS WATCHING MONICA'S GAME FROM THE GYM DOORW

text: Monica watches and her mom's droning voice disappears...
FELICIA, 17, can't get enough of Quincy's lips.
Yo, Felicia, I gotta get to my game. She keeps kissing him. QUINCY (cont'd)
And my mom's about to be home.
So I'm not good enough to meet your mom?
Girl, she knew I had a hottie like you up inhere, she'd beat the black off me.
(kissing him again)
That's a lot of beating. She finally lets go, and slides into her car.  Quincy wat her go with a cocky-ass smile.

A frenzied crowd from floor to ceiling watches Quincy exp across the court.  He is the complete point guard - hitti from the outside, driving to the hoop, no-look passes, playing tight D.' His father, Zeke, now 39, stands on the sideline.  His mu has softened a little over the last five years of retirem Monica sits alone in the bottom row, holding a basketball She wears jeans and a T-shirt and her hair is pulled back a simple pony-tail. Quincy does a killer cross-over move and his Defender fal down.  He lays up the ball, then taunts the player he jus poster-ized.  Behind Monica, TWO GIRLS smack each other excitedly.  One of them, SHAWNEE, 17, pretty, big chest, slides down into the empty seat next to her.
Hey, girl.
Hey.
Your hair looks so cute like that. Monica knows she's full of shit, doesn't respond. SHAWNEE (cont'd)
So...you know who Q's asking to the Spring Dance?
No.
C'mon, girl, you live next door.  Who's been creeping?
There's so many I just can't keep track.
Well, can you give him this for me? Shawnee holds out a folded note.  Monica doesn't take it.
Give it yourself.
I don't wanna look fast. (drops it in Monica's lap)
Thanks, girl. She slides back to her seat.  Monica shakes her head, tur back to the game. Quincy dives for a loose ball.  Shawnee clutches her frie SHAWNEE (cont'd)
Good Lord, look at that ass.  I just want to lick the sweat off it. Monica takes in his tight body.  He does look good.  Quin jogs back down court and flashbulbs go off...
Flashbulbs.  Quincy stands with his dad, his sweat still fresh, talking to a reporter named JIM.
Quincy, word has it you might make the jump the NBA.
Don't go starting rumors, Jim.  My son's college bound with or without basketball.
You could make a career by telling me where.
Gotta wait til the press conference.
But you'd love for him to play at USC, like you did.
I'd love for him to get a good education. (then)
That's it. Jim crosses away.  Zeke puts an affectionate arm around h son as they walk toward the locker room. ZEKE (cont'd)
We should have another talk with Coach Carril at Princeton.
Pop, there's no way an Ivy League Team is going all the way.
I don't care about the team.  I care about the school.
Didn't we already have this conversation? Zeke sighs, then:
You played good.  I was proud of you. Quincy smiles wide.
Yeah? (then)
So you up for a game later?
I don't wanna hurt your feelings.
You don't wanna hurt your back.
(smiles)
Anyway, I gotta get to this meeting. Tell your Mom I'm gonna be late.
You work too hard, Pop.
Let's hope I can say the same about you one day. Quincy watches his dad move toward the doors, stopping on to give an autograph.  Zeke passes Monica, entering.
Hey, Mr. M.
Hey, Miss Baller. He exits.  Monica approaches Quincy.
Way to hoop.
I know this.  What do you want?
A ride home.
Your legs don't look broke.
Look, big head, I'll be at your car.
Guess "please" would be a stretch.
(dryly)
Please.
Silence as Quincy wheels his Jeep Wrangler toward home. Monica sits in the passenger seat, basketball in lap.  Sh pulls Shawnee's note from her pocket.  Quincy glances it over.
What's that?
Some note Shawnee Easton told me to give to you.
(thinks)
Big-ass titties? Monica shoots him a disgusted look.  Quincy reaches out. QUINCY (cont'd)
Give it here. Monica leans away, reads aloud.
"Q.  I think you are so fine and I've been wanting to get with you.  Let me take you to the Spring Dance and I promise I'll leave you satisfied." Monica laughs in disbelief. MONICA (cont'd)
What a ho.
Why she gotta be a ho, just cause she wants to get with me.
She's a ho cause she's sending her coochie through the mail.
And?
And?  She's not saying, "I think you're a nice guy and I wanna get to know you better," she's saying, "I wanna bone."
So she's honest.
Yeah, an honest tramp-ass ho.  But I guess you'll stick your dick in anything.
Didn't know you cared so much.
I don't.
So who you going to the dance with, Spalding?
Who's Spalding? Quincy looks down at the SPALDING BASKETBALL in her lap a cracks up.  Monica glares. MONICA (cont'd)
Fuck you, Quincy.
See, that's why you ain't getting recruited.
Who said I'm not getting recruited?
Your hot-ass temper. Monica points to the scar on her cheek.
I'm not the one who put this scar here.
God, here we go.
When we were eleven years old cause he was about to lose. Quincy turns, faces her.
That's it, give it your best shot.
Would you watch the damn road?
I mean it, give it your best shot, cause I'm tired of you holding that over my head.
I'm warning you, don't tempt me.
I'm warning you.  You don't stall that bad attitude, no one's gonna recruit you. Quincy pulls his Jeep into his driveway.
Please, you jump in some guy's face, talk smack and you get a pat on your ass.  But because I'm a female, I get told to calm down and act like a "lady".  I'm a ballplayer, okay.  A ball player.
With a jacked-up attitude.
Didn't know you cared so much.
I don't.
Good. Monica slams out of the Jeep and walks across the lawn to house.  Quincy exits his ride.
Quincy steps inside, drops his bag on the floor.  His mom Nona, approaches from the dining room.
What's up, Moms. Nona holds up a large hoop earring.
What is this?
Uh, your earring?
I look like some hoochie to you?  I found it on your floor.
What are you doing in my room? Quincy crosses into:
Nona follows.  Quincy pulls open the fridge, grabs a coup of slices of cold pizza.
Quincy, I told you about these fat-ass girls.
We were just studying.
I'm not playing with you, these girls are looking to get you caught.  They see you, they see dollar signs.
Okay.
You hearing me?
I've been hearing you. Nona eyes her son, then lets up.  She gives him a kiss.
How was your game?
Twenty-seven points, eleven assists and still undefeated.
Still the man.
Yup. Nona smiles, starts back the kitchen.
Where's your dad?
Said he'd be home later.
Later when?
I don't know, he had a meeting or something. Quincy exits to his room.
Nona angrily rolls her hair as Zeke undresses.
I had some players to see and hands to shake.
At one in the morning?
I'm not gonna get anywhere punching a clock just so my wife doesn't get an attitude.
I came second to the NBA.  I'm not about to come second to this bullshit scouting job. Zeke looks at her, offended. NONA (cont'd)
I didn't mean it like that.
Yeah.
I'm just saying it'd be nice if you found time for your family. You should see the tramps coming after Quincy.  If you don't talk to him...
I have. A beat.
You said you'd think about going back to get your degree.

No, you said I should get my degree.  I like my "bullshit" job, okay, and it's gonna lead to a spot in the front office. Til then, don't worry, there's just enough savings to keep your ass in Gucci and gold. Livid, Nona pulls off her gold bracelet, throws it at him
Fine, then how many nights home is that?
Keep your voice down. She grabs a pair of gold earrings from her jewelry box, n him.
How about now?  I got a week yet?
Quincy lies in bed, staring at the ceiling, as his parent continue to have it out. He rolls out of bed, pulls on a pair of shorts and a T-sh He moves to his window, pulls it open and climbs out...
Quincy crosses the grass to Monica's window, knocks quiet Long beat, then Monica sleepily stumbles to her window, wearing boxers and a tank top.  She pushes it open and Qu pulls himself through...

Now a routine, Monica tosses Quincy one of her pillows an blankets, then crawls back into bed. He lays out on the floor and closes his eyes.  Monica cas long, sleepy glance at him, then drifts back to sleep.

Posters of Magic line three walls.  A hand-made collage o female college and Olympic ball-players fills the fourth. The only real "soft" touch is the teddy bear laying on th pillow. Monica sits on the floor between Lena's legs, as Lena put Monica's hair in cornrows.
That too tight?
No.
Mom's going to hate it.
Always on my ass, anyway.
Like you don't give her a hard time.
Just cause I don't kiss her booty like you... Lena yanks Monica's head back. MONICA (cont'd)
Ow!!!
You need to.  She's alone in this house all day, taking care of Dad and your ungrateful behind.
No one's forcing her.
Just try and chill a little bit, alright. Monica doesn't answer.  Lena yanks her head back again.
Ow!!!  Okay! They crack up.
So what's going on with the Spring Dance? You have a date yet?
(sarcastically)
Yeah, brothers are lined up at my locker.
I found you someone.
Found?  I'm not some charity case.
I know...
Mom tell you to do this?
No.
Damn, Lena... (then)
Who is he?
This brother from my college.
He's in college?
And he's fine, girl.
How'd you get him to say yes?
I told him you looked like me.
Oh, great.
You do.

Anyway, I told your mom I wanted to be the one who told you.
Tell me what?
I just told you.
I mean, it's not true, is it? Zeke stares at his son.
You got the balls to ask me that? Quincy can't hold his father's look.  Zeke shakes his hea hurt.
Sorry.
No, you need to hear me say it, I'll say it.  It's not true. Quincy looks in his father's eyes, knows he's telling the truth.
So what are you gonna do?
I want this thing to go to court, but my lawyer's telling me to settle.
Why?
A case like this could hang around for months and I'm up for this player relations job with the "Clips."  This gets out, false or not, no one'll touch me.
What's Mom think?

We haven't exactly been living the fairy- tale life the past few years.  Something like this happens, it either brings a family closer or pushes them further apart.  We'll just have to see how it plays out. (then)
I'm giving her some space, couple days... Just then, a COLLEGE STUDENT approaches.
Yo, Q-man, great game.
Thanks. The student holds out a piece of paper, without even a gl to Zeke.
Can I get an autograph? Quincy nods, signs the guy's paper.  Zeke watches his son the rising star.

Through the windows, we see Quincy enter the house.  He glances around, then walks to the living room.  He sees h mom sitting outside by the pool, drink in hand, looking t up.  He pulls open the sliding glass door.  Nona jumps, t sees Quincy.  She quickly puts her drink down.
You scared me.
Sorry.  You okay?
I'm fine. Quincy glances at her half-hidden glass.
Last time I remember you drinking was when Marvin Gaye died. No response from Nona. QUINCY (cont'd)
This about Dad?
Guess he talked to you.
Don't sweat it, okay.  Sooner or later the truth'll come out.
(beat)
Whose truth are you talking about?
Mom, we can't let something like this mess up the family. She doesn't respond.  Quincy studies her. QUINCY (cont'd)
I mean, you believe him, right? Nona sits silent, humiliated. QUINCY (cont'd)
Mom?
Just...leave it alone.
This is just about money, you know that.
Quincy, please...
I mean, how many times have you told me yourself to watch out for these ho's?
Guess I should have been telling your father.

So you're gonna take the word of some trick over Pop's?  He wouldn't lie. Nona grabs an envelope beside her and throws it at him. Confused, Quincy opens it.  HE PULLS OUT A COUPLE OF PHOT Zeke outside a party.  IN ONE PHOTO, his arm is around a young woman.  IN ANOTHER PHOTO, they KISS.  AND YET ANOTH they climb into his car. QUINCY (cont'd)
What...what's this?
I hired somebody.  How pathetic is that? After all his late nights and "meetings" and I still needed proof. Quincy just stares at the photos. NONA (cont'd)
I used to think I was lucky just to be married to Zeke McCall, but I'm too tired. Quincy looks stricken, but he moves to Nona, comforts her she cries...
Monica sits with a devastated Quincy, high up in the bleachers.  In the distance, the clock-tower glows 10:50.
Don't put your hands in your pockets, hold your head up, always look a man in the eye, and all the time I'm hanging on his every word like he's God or something...
I know he messed up, but that doesn't change what he's been to you.
What has he been to me?  I mean, he looked me in my face and lied like it was nothing.  Like it was easy. (then)
And I'm standing there getting loud on my mom like she's the one with no sense...
She understands.
He even had me wanting to play for the "Clippers."  Man, how stupid am I.
You're not stupid.

I know a lot of brothers dog their wives, I just never thought my pops would do some shit like this... Monica puts her arms around him.  They sit there, quiet. Monica glances up at the clock tower.  She reacts.  Quinc notices. QUINCY (cont'd)
What?
Nothing. (beat)
Why don't we walk to my dorm?
I'm not up for running into anybody. Let's just kick it here, alright?
I...can't.
Why not?
Coach has us on eleven o'clock curfew. If I'm late, I don't suit up. Quincy looks at her, almost in shock.
Didn't realize you were watching the clock.
I mean, I can stay a few more minutes.
Nah.  Don't sweat it.
Quincy...
For real.  I should be alone, anyway. Monica reluctantly stands.
Will you call me when you get in? Quincy nods.  Monica gives him a kiss.  Then she turns an crosses away.
The lights are off but Monica sits up in bed.  SHE WEARS BOXERS AND ONE OF QUINCY'S PRACTICE SHIRTS. Shayla lies under her covers across the room.
I shouldn't have left.
Go to sleep.
You should have seen him, Shay...

Mon, Sidra's out for one game, and you got the start.  But you get caught breaking curfew and Coach is gonna send your ass back to the bench.  You'll see your man tomorrow. Shayla's warning slowly sinks in.  Finally, Monica lays d
The clock tower glows 12:30.  Quincy still sits in the bleachers.  Alone.  Tears fill his eyes as his world come crashing down...

USC vs. Louisiana Tech.  The packed crowd is hyped.  Nath sits by himself in the stands, excited. Monica sits on the bench with four of her teammates.  The rest of the team is lined up in front of them, including Sidra in street clothes.
And now the starting line-up for your Women of Troy!  At center, a senior, Toni Noise! Toni rises, jogs through the line of teammates to the cou ANNOUNCER (cont'd)
At forward, a senior, Lisa Mason! Lisa stands, skips through the line. ANNOUNCER (cont'd)
At forward, a junior, Zvette Mitchell! Zvette jumps up, bumps into each teammate as she moves do the line. ANNOUNCER (cont'd)
At guard, a freshman, Monica Wright! Monica takes a deep breath, then jogs through the line. gets to the middle of the floor and looks around with her game face on. ANNOUNCER (cont'd)
And at guard, a sophomore, Sandra Perez! Sandra jogs out and the rest of the team follows.  Everyo gathers in a tight circle with their arms around each oth

Look y'all, we got all these people here to see big-bad, La Tech.  We need to let them know that this is our house.  So everybody better leave everything out on that floor, you got that?  Ready?  One, two, three....
Team!

A sellout crowd for the men's SC/Temple game.  And Quincy having the worst game of his life. He drives down court on a fast break.  He ignores his two open teammates and puts up a three-pointer.  It hits noth but air.  The crowd boos. Humiliated, Quincy tries to steal the ball back and commi stupid foul.  His teammates glare at him as they line up free throws.

Monica's game.  Late second half.  SC down two. Monica drives the lane, drawing two defenders.  She looks like she's about to force up a shot, then suddenly whips pass to a wide-open Sandra at the three-point line.  Noth but net.  SC up one. Coach Miller claps intensely on the sideline.

That's it, that's it! Ten seconds left.  Game on the line.  Monica tries to lob pass inside to Toni.  The pass is knocked away and grabbe by the opposing point guard. It is a one-on-one between Monica and the guard.  The gir drives hard for the winning hoop.  Monica races to the ke and slides in front of her.  The guard goes up and slams Monica.  Both crash to the floor as the ball drops throug the net and the buzzer goes off. A WHISTLE.  The two women stare up at the REFEREE from th floor.  And then --
Offensive foul!  Charging!  No basket! Monica leaps up as the crowd goes crazy.  Toni grabs up Monica in a hug as their teammates celebrate around them.
Quincy drags himself to his bench, slumps down dejectedly the Temple Owls celebrate their win around him.
The female players continue to celebrate as they undress.
Shoot, you see that crowd?  We need to be playing in the Sports Arena.
Hell yeah. They give each other a pound. Lisa looks at Monica, standing in her shorts and sports b
Oh damn, Mon.
What?
I think ol' girl took out your chi-chis with that charge. The women break into laughter.  Monica smiles.
Kiss my ass.
Nah, I think she took that too.
Sandra, please, last time you chest- bumped me, it took you three tries. More laughter.  Monica looks over at Toni, sitting quietl the bench. MONICA (cont'd)
Yo, T, why you so quiet?
(beat)
I don't want to go play overseas.
I thought you were hyped about going to Portugal next year.
It's never gonna be like this.  Playing in front of my family, hanging out with my girls.  Probably not even a McDonald's.
Nah, there's always a McDonald's.
Least you got an offer.  My agent's still looking.
(to Lisa)
What about you?
(beat)
Maybe it'd be worth it if I knew some day I could come back here and play.  But for right now, it's law school.
Monica. Monica turns, sees Coach Miller standing in her office doorway.  She motions for her.  Monica heads over.  Sidra watches.
Trophies, plaques and photos fill every empty space. Coach Miller sits behind her desk.  Monica stands before
You could've given up after you threw that ball away.  But you kept your head and you showed real heart.
Thanks.
We've got our final games against Oregon and Oregon State and I want to shake things up a bit, so I'm starting you at point again.
(confused)
I thought Sidra's ankle was okay for next game.
You want the job or not? Realization finally hits.
Yeah.  Yes. Monica looks at Coach Miller completely thrown.
What?
It's just...it seems like you're always yelling at me.
You think I'd go hoarse for a player with no potential?   When I ignore you, that's when you worry. (then)
Go get dressed. Monica nods, crosses out.
As Monica walks back to her teammates, Coach Miller steps into the doorway.
Sidra. Sidra looks at Monica as she rises, crosses over.  Monica avoids her eyes as they pass.  Sidra enters the office an the door closes.
Yo sis, what's going on? Beat, then Monica smiles.
Black folks pack the cramped houseparty, bumping to a pha hip hop joint. Monica bounces through the throng.  A GIRL grabs her arm.
Yo, great game.
Thanks. Another PARTY-GOER grabs her arm.
Girl, you can play. Monica smiles wider.  She spots Reggie dancing in the cro moves to him.
Reg.  You seen Quincy?
What's up, girl.
(louder)
Derek said Q was here.
We'll roll through. Monica is suddenly pulled into a dance routine by Sandra Lisa. She laughs, tires to move away, but they won't let her go Monica gives in, grooves with them.

Quincy walks through the door with a half-empty forty in hand.  Girls immediately try to grab his attention from t dance floor, or stare him down from the sidelines. Quincy sees Monica on the dance floor.  He stands, watchi her.  Takes a drink.  Monica finally looks over, sees him She smiles, crosses to him.
Hey.
What's up?
I've been trying to find you all day.
Here I am. She glances at the forty in his hand.
Sorry about your game.
It happens, right... Shayla suddenly grabs Monica from behind.
(to Monica)
What's up, superstar. (then, to Quincy)
Your girl was on tonight.  She tell you?
(beat)
I heard.
She also tell you she ganked the starting spot from Sidra? Monica looks at him for a reaction.
Nah. He downs the last of his forty. QUINCY (cont'd)
Where's the keg at?
Balcony. He heads for the glass doors.  Monica and Shayla follow.
Reggie approaches the group.  Gives Quincy a nod.
What's up, dog? (to Shayla)
Hey, flyness.
Get off the bra strap, Reggie, you're a ho. He laughs, then turns back to Quincy.
Coach is gonna kill us in practice tomorrow.  Might even pull his lips off your dick, limp as your game was tonight. Quincy just looks at him.
That's funny. Monica leans against Quincy, affectionately.
he's just playing, Q...
You think for once we could talk about something besides basketball?
Sure.
Whatever's clever. Silence.  Reggie and Shayla crack up.  Quincy shakes his head, moves to the keg line.
Y'all need to quit. She starts for Quincy
Monica. Monica looks over, sees Sidra standing in the doorway.  T is no escaping this confrontation.  She glances at Quincy then crosses over.  Quincy turns, sees her disappear back inside.
What's up?
Just wanted to say good game.
But?
No buts.  Took a lot of heart to take that charge.
Thanks.
But that was a dumb-ass pass to Toni. Ten seconds left, you run out the clock. Monica shakes her head.  An awkward silence. SIDRA (cont'd)
I'd be lying if I said I wasn't pissed.
I know.
Just one word of advice for next season.
What's that?
Never let a freshman take your spot. Sidra turns and walks away.
Quincy takes one long drink from his cup.  KERRY, 20, and spandexed, stands directly in front of him, flirtatiously
Excuse me.
Excuse me. He steps aside as she tries to work the keg.  Nothing com out.  She nods at his cup, smiles.
If that's the last beer, you and I are sharing. Shayla glances over as Quincy pumps the keg a couple of times.  Kerry hands him her cup and he starts filling it KERRY (cont'd)
I like watching you play.  Number twenty- two.
Guess you didn't see the game. Quincy knows he should blow her off, but he's digging the attention.  He hands her back her cup. QUINCY (cont'd)
What's your name?
Kerry.
I know.
Monica looks over at Quincy and sees him talking to the hoochie.  The girl looks too damn comfortable.  Monica mo back outside. KERRY (cont'd)
I'll see you.  Q-man. She swishes past Monica.  Shayla "accidentally" bumps her Kerry glares.
Who was that?
Nobody.
Who's nobody?
Look, this party's whack.  You ready to go?
You want to go talk?
Not really. He leans in, kisses her drunkenly.  She pulls away.
We could finish what we were talking about last night. Quincy kisses her again. MONICA (cont'd)
(pushing him off)
Quincy, quit.  You're drunk. They fall silent.
You know what, I'm just gonna crash.
(agitated)
Fine...Maybe I'll come by later.
Nah.  I have curfew. He starts to walk away, then stops. QUINCY (cont'd)
Oh, by the way.  Congratulations. He goes.  Monica stares after him.
Quincy pushes through his front door, then stops short in doorway.  Zeke sits on the couch.
What are you doing here?
Your door was unlocked.
Still is, so let yourself out.
We need to talk.
We ain't got nothing to talk about.
I messed up, okay, I know that.  But I ain't that kid's father.
Lucky kid.
Look, I ain't saying it was right, but sometimes things happen.
And some things should never fucking happen!
Boy, you're so perfect you can look down on me?
I ain't a damn liar.

Your mom was real quick to show you those pictures, wasn't she? Well, she was nineteen when she got pregnant and don't get me wrong, you're the best thing in my life, but she knew I wasn't ready for no marriage.
So now you're saying my mother trapped you?

I'm saying I handled my responsibilities like a man.  But when you're in the NBA, you pull into a city and there's a hundred women waiting at the hotel.  And another twenty that made it past security on your floor.  And the boldest one is standing right at your door.  And after awhile, it just becomes part of the game. (then)
I'm sorry I lied to you, I shouldn't have.  But I did it cause I love you. Zeke looks at his son, meaning every word.  Quincy stares back, long and hard.
Since we're being honest, guess I should tell you.  I'm dropping out of school and going pro.
What? Quincy just stares back. ZEKE (cont'd)
Quincy, you'd be making the biggest mistake of your life.
(sarcastic)
From your mouth.
(desperate)
I know your mad at me, okay, but I can't let you do this.
Always thought "can't" wasn't in a man's vocabulary. Zeke is taken aback by the hatred in his son's eyes.  He turns and without another word, exits.
Quincy stands across the street from the houseparty, star up at the balcony.  Monica leans against the railing, laughing with a couple of teammates.  Quincy watches her, then turns and walks away...

SLOW MOTION.  Monica's eyes are on fire as she races an Oregon player for a loose ball.  Both dive for it, slide across the floor.  Monica grabs it up, screams for a time as her opponent tries to wrestle away the ball...
Monica walks down the hall to Quincy's suite.  The window open.  The sounds of Nintendo are heard.  She walks in without knocking.
Reggie sits on the couch with a TEAMMATE, playing Nintend "Duck Hunt".
Hey, y'all. They barely give her a nod.  Monica crosses into
Quincy stands at an ironing board, ironing a T-shirt.
Hey.
Hey, what's up.
You weren't at my game.
Yeah, sorry about that.  I had this meeting with this guy. Quincy pulls on the T-shirt. QUINCY (cont'd)
You win?
Yeah, I hit a three at the buzzer.
The "man" again.
(smiles)
Woman... A knock at the front door.  Quincy exits.
Monica follows, then stops short.  Kerry, the spandexed g from the party, stands in the doorway.
Hey, you.
Hi. Quincy gives her a hug.  Monica stares at him in disbelie Reggie and his teammate smack each other, "Oh shit!"
Oh, Kerry, this is Monica.  Monica, Kerry.
What the hell's going on?
We're going to get some food.
Are you out of your mind?
Maybe I should come back?
No.  You stay, I'll leave. She storms out.
BAM!  Monica slams her car door.  Her face is a mask of a and confusion. Camille exits the house, car keys in hand.  She sees her.
Monica.  What are you doing here?
Didn't know I needed a reason to come home.
Don't be defensive.  I'm just surprised to see you.
Dad around?
He's still at the bank. Monica glowers.  Camille looks at her. CAMILLE (cont'd)
Everything okay?
(clearly not)
Yeah. Camille just nods, doesn't bother asking again.
Well, I'm going to get dinner. She pulls open her car door.  Beat, then... CAMILLE (cont'd)
It's just a game.
What?
Whenever you lose, you get this attitude. But it's just a game. Monica rolls her eyes, as her mom leaves.
Quincy sits on the wall outside of Monica's dorm, as Moni slowly makes her way up the walk.  She sees him, stops.
Can we talk?
Talk to your new girlfriend.
I just took the ho to Burger King, alright.
Cheap date.
Least she had time for me.
So you fucked around to prove a point!
I just said I didn't fuck around.  But you got your head so far up your ass it took a cheap date for you to notice me.
What, "Q-man", did I forget to kiss your ass like everybody else?
You forgot to be there.
That night you wanted to talk about your Dad I had a curfew.  What was I supposed to do?
Stay!
If I stayed, I wouldn't be starting!
Least you got your priorities straight.
I never asked you to choose.
Never had to.
I'm a ballplayer.  If anyone knows what that means it should be you.
Well, if all you care about is basketball, why you fucking me?  Go fuck Dick Vitale. Monica punches the shit out of Quincy, then pushes past h Quincy grabs her arm, stopping her. QUINCY (cont'd)
Hold up.  I'm sorry, alright. They stand, silent.  Trying to come down from their anger
How do I know next time you're feeling neglected or whatever, you're not going to run around on me?  If we're going to be together I have to be able to trust you.
I'm not asking for us to be together. Monica flinches in shock.
What?
I'm going through a lot of shit right now, more than you have time for.
How are you going to tell me what I have time for?  I mean, whatever I did...we can fix this.
I don't think so.
You don't think so?
Look, I'm entering the draft.
You're what?
I decided to go pro.  And who knows where I'll end up, you know? Monica's heart is sinking fast.
When did you decide all this?
Few days ago.
So that's it, just forget about us?
Damnitt, Monica.  This ain't about us anymore, it's about me. Monica is crushed.  Beat as, Quincy struggles to stay col QUINCY (cont'd)
But, you know, I'd still like us to be friends.
Friends. She fights back tears.  Quincy has to look away.  Monica can't respond.
So...I guess I'll see you around.
Uh huh. Beat, then Quincy turns and walks away.  Monica tries to fight her tears but her pain, hurt and confusion are too much.  Finally, she gives in, and the tears fall.
FOOTAGE.  Press conference.  Magic sits beside his wife Cookie.  He shocks the world as he announces his retireme from basketball.
TITLE CARD: "FOURTH QUARTER" then "1993"
Madrid, Pampolona, the running of the bulls, old-world architecture. Finally, we rest on a large billboard, a photo of Monica basketball uniform, drinking a Spanish soft-drink.

Monica jogs down the congested cobble-stone street, a spo bag over her shoulder.  She is TWENTY-THREE.  Half-assed braids frame her matured features. She passes store fronts, street vendors, and dodges pedestrians, as she makes her way toward a large, older arena.

An excited crowd jockeys for position at the front doors. Above them, a huge banner reads "Campeonato de Europeo". (European Championships".) As Monica heads for the back entrance, a cheer goes up fr large contingent in the crowd.  Monica smiles, waves back TWO LITTLE GIRLS break from line, run to her.
Baloncesto!  Balencesto!  (Basketball! Basketball!)
Oye. They giggle, hold out a piece of paper and a pencil.
Autografo. As Monica signs her autograph, a tall woman carrying a matching sports bag approaches.  She is LUISA, Spanish, 3
(thick Spanish accent)
Monica.  What is up?
Oye, Luisa. Monica hands the girls her autograph and they run off.
Large game, no?
Si.  Large game. They duck into the arena.

Paint peels off the walls.  Windows are broken overhead. Monica sits alone at her locker, taping her own ankles. TEN TEAMMATES, all from Spain, sit on the surrounding benches, talking and joking among themselves in Spanish. Monica is clearly an outsider. COACH PARRA, Spanish, late 40's, enters.

Silenco! The women immediately stop talking.  COACH PARRA gives an animated, impassioned speech in Spanish.  Monica doesn't understand a word, just continues taping her ankles. Coach Parra finishes and the women clap, pumped up. Monic turns to Luisa, seated next to her on the bench.
What did he say?
He say to give the ball to you.

The arena is PACKED with a raucous European crowd, chanti and waving signs - the love their women's basketball. Monica walks onto the floor, tucking her jersey into her shorts.  The uniforms are old-style - polyester and tight Her club's name is stitched on the front, "GODELLA". As she hits center court, a smile suddenly breaks through game face.  Standing opposite her, playing for the opposi Italian club is Sidra, HER RIVAL FROM USC.
Well, what do you know.
What's up, Sidra.
I'm gonna love winning this championship in your house.

How do you say "you're dreaming" in Italian? They move into position.  The ball is tossed up.  Italy w the tip and the ball is passed to Sidra. Monica hounds her as she brings up the ball.  Sidra shove her off and to the floor, and scores.  No whistle.  Women pro ball is at a whole other level.  Bigger, better, toug The ball is passed in to Monica.  She drives down court, up for a lay up.  An Italian player shoves Monica in mid- taking out her legs.  Monica crashes on the hardwood. A whistle.  Monica lays still for a moment, then pushes herself up and walks to the free-throw line without a wor Without emotion.

A huge crowd dances fervently to the live Spanish music. the middle of the floor, the Spanish players are the life the party. In a corner, Monica sits with Sidra, drinking and watchin the festivities.  A large trophy sits on the table.
Can you take that damn thing off the table.
You mean my championship trophy?  My bad. Monica sets it down in the seat next to her, puts an arm around it.  Sidra shakes her head.
Still a cocky bitch. Monica laughs.  She downs her drink, motions to the waite
Uno mas, por favor. The waiter nods. MONICA (cont'd)
Last I heard, you were playing in Sweden.

Yeah, four years ago.  They had me staying in this tiny-ass town with like fifty people.  I'm not playing, there was about a thousand goats running around, and it gets dark at four o'clock.  Then the whack club I'm on loses three games in a row and I get blamed.  So they fire me.
Just like that?
Yup.  So I've been playing with this Italian club the last three years.
How's that been?
It's better.  Even though the whole first season my teammates didn't pass to me cause they were mad "The American" was making more money. (smiles)

I led the team in rebounds cause it was the only way I could touch the damn ball. Monica laughs as the waiter brings her drink.  She tries pay, but he just shakes his head, crosses away. SIDRA (cont'd)
Most of us don't win championships our first year overseas.

Please, I went through the same drama as everybody else.  I mean, the first four months, only person I could talk to was this chick Luisa, who knew like ten words of English from watching old "Dif'rent Strokes" reruns.  Swear to God, I had to tell her if she said, "What you talking bout, Willis?" one more time, I was gonna kick her ass. Sidra laughs.  They watch the madness out on the dance fl
So what are these Spanish guys like?
I wouldn't know.
What?  You've been over here seven months and you ain't tapped anything?
Just not my type, I guess.
Shoot, Italian boys love them some black women.  They can't get enough of me. Monica smiles.
You ever think about going back?
Sometimes.  But what's the alternative, not playing?  You remember big Toni? (off Monica's nod)

She quit last year, now she's working at some bookstore.  I mean, look at us. They treat us like we're Hollywood stars over here.  We just played in the championship game.  It doesn't get much sweeter than this. Monica takes this in.  Her eyes do not reflect someone on of the world.  She takes a long drink.

A small, sparse, one-bedroom.  Sam, Diane and the rest of gang from "Cheers" fill the small TV screen that flickers the darkness.  Their dialogue is dubbed in Spanish. Monica sits on the floor, braiding her hair.

head_text.subj: SHE WEARS BOXERS AND QUINCY'S OLD PRACTICE SHIRT. AFTER

text: Feelings of loneliness threaten to swallow her whole.  Sh looks out her window and sees her billboard, looming in t distance.  She just stares.
The crowd erupts as a Laker player dunks the ball on a fa break.
Laker announcers CHICK HEARN and STU LANTZ.
Stu, this game is in the refrigerator. The door is closed, the lights are out, the butter's hard and the Jell-Oooooo's jigglin'.
And here come the subs.

Quincy pulls off his sweats and jogs onto the court with rest of the subs.  He is twenty-three, a man.  His goatee tired eyes make him look older.  HE NOW WEARS NUMBER TWEN ONE. STU LANTZ (cont'd) (V.O.)
It's good to see these guys get a little playing time.  And the fans love it. Quincy immediately gets a pass in the corner.  He puts up quick three and it banks hard off the rim.
Chick and Stu.
Three-pointer is off for the kid from SC.  Came out after his freshman year, now in his fifth year with the league.
The son of Zeke McCall, played twelve years with the Clippers.
(nods)
Pretty good player.  The kid's moved around quite a bit, but he's hoping to finally have a home with the Lakers.
Quincy steals the ball, has nothing but open court ahead him. CHICK HEARN (cont'd) (V.O.)

Watch out, folks, it's showtime. Quincy takes off from the hash-mark and throws down a mon jam.  He swings high off the rim.  Too high.  His hand sl and he crashes to the floor.  His knee twists at a sicken angle. The dwindling crowd gasps as Quincy clutches his left kne writhing in pain.
Zeke walks down the corridor, checking room numbers.  He forty-five now.  His slight paunch as become a roll. He sees Nona exiting a room, with an empty water pitcher hand.  Her hair is in locks.
Nona. Nona looks over.  Her eyes narrow. ZEKE (cont'd)
How's he doing?
Not great.
What's that, not great?
The doctor'll be back in a minute.
Nona, please.
He tore his ACL. Zeke's shoulders slump.  Then he looks back at her.
Almost didn't recognize you with your hair like that.  How you been?

Happy.  And he won't want to see you. Nona walks over to a MAN standing nearby.  He puts an arm around her and they move down the hall.  Zeke watches for beat, then pulls open Quincy's door, steps inside.
Quincy lays in the bed.  His knee is bandaged and propped by pillows.  He stares out the window.
Hey, son. Quincy turns, sees his father.  He turns back to the wind ZEKE (cont'd)
Well, you made SportsCenter.
What do you want?
Came by to check on you.
After five years.
Don't remember that being my fault. Seems like you divorced me same time as your mom.
Look, I'm busy.
I can see that.  I know things look pretty bleak right now, but you can't get down on yourself.
I stopped taking your advice a long time ago, or did you forget?
No.
Good.
Quincy.  I know you left school early to throw your middle finger up at me.
And now I'm paying for it, right?  That what this is about?  "I told you so?"
You want me to fuck off?
Yeah.
Fine, I'll fuck off, but not til I say something. Silence.  Then. ZEKE (cont'd)

You're a better ballplayer than I ever was.  But you got a lot of other things going for you.  You're smart.  I always felt...I always knew that you could do anything you wanted.  You want to be a ballplayer, be a ballplayer.  Just know you ain't like everybody else on that court.  You ain't like I was.  You got options.  That's all I ever tried to show you.
You're still trying to tell me what I should and shouldn't do.  How come you couldn't be the man you kept trying to make me? Zeke stares at his son, wishing he could satisfy him with answer.
I just couldn't With nothing left to say, Zeke pulls open the door and leaves.  Quincy stares at the door long after it closes.

A NURSE enters, carrying a bouquet of flowers.  She moves past the empty bed, puts them on a table already overflow with flowers.  She pulls open the blinds and light floods room.  She crosses back out. A toilet flush.  Beat, then Quincy slowly hops out of the bathroom, scratching his bare ass through the opening of gown.
And I thought this was gonna be awkward. Quincy whips around and is shocked to see Monica standing there, laughing.  She has clearly made an effort with her appearance.
Monica? He stumbles.  Monica quickly goes to him, catches his arm before he falls.
I'm sorry. Quincy stares at her, completely thrown.  It's been five years.  An awkward beat. MONICA (cont'd)
So, how you doing?
Alright.  I heard you were in Spain.
I was. (smiling)
I see your peach fuzz finally grew in. Quincy rubs his goatee self-consciously.
Just something I'm trying.
No, it looks good.  I mean, it's cool.
Thanks. Quincy tries to adjust his footing and flinches in pain.
Shouldn't you be lying down, or...
I'm alright.  But you can sit.
I'm fine.  My dad said you tore your ACL.
Yup.
What are the doctors saying?
(shrugs)
A lot of things.  All I know is I'll be back in six months.
I thought a torn ACL was ten to twelve.
Not for Quincy McCall.
I forgot, "Q-man." An awkward beat.
So, how's pro-ball, Europe?
We won the championship.
Still working on being the first girl in the NBA?
Well, I tried sneaking in after college, but they found breasts during my physical.
Funny.  I never did.
Kiss my ass. Monica cracks up.  Quincy laughs with her. MONICA (cont'd)
I can't believe it's been five years. Quincy nods.
Tried calling you a couple times.
Oh yeah?
Wanted to give you props on making First Team All-American.  And then when Magic retired, I tried calling you again.
(lying)
Must have been my cheap-ass answering machine.  It was always messing up.
Figured it was something like that. They look at each other.  The moment is building. QUINCY (cont'd)
So, when do you go back?
Actually, I don't...
What do you mean?
I'm tired of playing overseas.  Thinking about giving it a rest for awhile.
(completely thrown)
A rest?
Yeah.  Basketball just, isn't fun anymore.  You know?
No. He stares at her.  Into her.
Quincy! Quincy and Monica turn, as KYRA KESSLER, black, 26 and beautiful, rushes into the room.  She wears a flight attendant's uniform.  She goes to Quincy, gives him a kis Monica reacts.
I'm so sorry.  No one would switch flights with me.
It's okay.
Why are you up?  Get in bed. She takes Quincy's arm, moves him to the bed.  Monica watches. KYRA (cont'd)
Tell me you're going to be okay.
I'm gonna be okay. Kyra relaxes.  Then she glances over at Monica.
Hello.
Kyra, this is Monica.  She, uh...
(recognizing)
Monica.  You grew up together, right? Quincy's told me about you. Monica smiles awkwardly.
This is Kyra.  My fiance. The shock hits too quick to cover.  But Monica tries.
Fiance.  Wow.  Congratulations.
Thank you.
I didn't know.  Wow.  That's great. (then)
Well...I should go.
It means a lot that you came by.
Yes, we appreciate that.
Yeah, and Quincy, good luck with your knee, and everything.
Thanks. Monica forces one last smile, pulls open the door and lea
Monica walks down the hall, shell-shocked.
Camille moves between the counter and the stove, whipping a couple pecan pies.  Monica enters.
Hey.
Hi.
Need any help?
I can manage. Monica nods and moves to the barstool. CAMILLE (cont'd)
Your sister's bringing the baby over. You should try to be here.
Yeah.  Can't wait to see him (she falls silent, then)
I just saw Quincy.
How is he?
Engaged.
To that stewardess?
Yeah, you met her?
His mother had a cookout a few weeks ago. He could do a lot better if you ask me.
Maybe she is. Camille looks up, studies Monica for a moment.
I thought you were over him. Monica shrugs.
So what do I do?
Find out where they're registered and send them a gift.
(disgusted)
Whatever.
You didn't want my opinion in the first place, so why even ask?
I asked but why does it always have to be so damn prissy.
Don't curse.
There you go.

What do you want me to tell you, Monica, to go beat that girl up?  To go have sex with him?  I'm not going to do that. Yes, I believe thinking of other people is important and yes I'd rather bake a pie than shoot a dumb jump shot.  If that makes me too "prissy" for you, too bad. Monica stares at her mother.  There's no going back.
So that's why we can't get along? Because I'd rather shoot a "dumb" jump shot?
You're the one always turning your nose up at me.
No I don't.
Child, please.  Ever since you were little you thought you were too good for anything I had to say.
I wasn't Lena.  I didn't care about nail polish or lip gloss or sneaking a spray of your perfume.
What was so wrong with wanting to teach you the things I knew could help you?
Because you're pushing me to be something I'm not.
So you're angry with me because you're standing here with your hair combed and wearing perfume? Monica is busted.  It takes her a moment to come back.
I'm angry because I want a mother, not Martha Stewart.
Oh, yes.  The superstar female athlete whose mother is nothing but a housewife.
That's not it.
Don't tell me you aren't ashamed of that because I know. Monica stares at her mother.

I remember when I was eight years old, you spent like four hours cooking up this fancy meal.  All you'd let me and Lena do was set the table.  And I guess you and Dad got your wires crossed or something because he walks in with a couple of pizzas.  And you didn't say anything. You just threw the whole meal into some tupper-ware and tossed it in the fridge.
I don't remember that.
I do.  You never stood up for yourself. Ever.  If I was ashamed, it was because of that.
That's ridiculous.

What's ridiculous is not being a caterer so your husband can feel like a man knowing his woman's home cooking and ironing his drawers. WHAP!  Camille's humiliation is immediate and she cuts of Monica with a SLAP.  Camille curses herself for losing it
Dammitt, Monica! Monica is stunned, hurt.
I'm sorry. Camille stares at her daughter, devastated.
Is that really all you think of me? Monica can't answer. CAMILLE (cont'd)

When I married your father, all I wanted was a nice house with a big kitchen so I could start my catering business.  And then I got pregnant with Lena, and then I got pregnant with you.  And I put it out of my mind because that's what you did. Monica stares at her mother. CAMILLE (cont'd)

But you want to know what day I remember? In high school, you getting ready for the Spring Dance.  I put my pearls around your neck, told you you were beautiful and you looked like you were going to cry.  That day I was happy I didn't have a catering business to run off to.  My family had three meals a day, had someone to pick up after them, and when my daughters went to a dance, I helped them get ready.  That's what I came to care about.
(softly)
That's all you cared about.  I must have played in a thousand games and I can only remember you being to two.
You had your coaches and your father for that stuff.  It never mattered one way or the other if I went to your games.
It mattered, Mom. Camille looks at her daughter and is struck by the need i her eyes.  Monica moves off the barstool and leaves.

The room looks exactly the same.  Trophies, medals, plaqu Basketball posters and her "strong women" wall. Monica sits on her bed, staring up at a photo of her and Quincy, tacked up to her bulletin board, amid other photo her childhood.  THEY ARE EIGHTEEN, PLAYFULLY WRESTLING OV BASKETBALL. Monica slowly rises, starts taking her posters down.

Quincy sits on a leg extension machine, with his left leg tucked under the padded bar.  A TRAINER stands behind him Sweat and pain coat Quincy's face and scarred knee as he slowly lifts the light weight again, and again, and again

A long line of customers shift impatiently during the noo time rush. Monica sits with a BANK MANAGER at the "New Accounts" des learning the ropes.  Her hair is done, she wears a simple dress.  Behind her, hanging on the wall, are three framed photos of the bank presidents.  ONE OF THEM IS HER FATHER NATHAN.
Monica stands in her room, staring out at Quincy's window She watches as Quincy and Kyra pack up some of Quincy's stuff.  Quincy tries to take his basketball globe light. laughs, "Hell no."

Camille enters, moves to Monica's garbage can, dumps the contents into her larger bag.  Suddenly, she stops.  She reaches into the garbage and pulls out a crumpled picture Camille smooths it.  It is the photo of Monica and Quincy eighteen, wrestling over a basketball.

head_text.subj: CAMILLE STARES AT IT, TAKEN IN BY THE PURE JOY IN HER

text: DAUGHTER'S FACE.  She sits down on Monica's bed, still staring.

In the empty gym, Quincy jogs up and down the court.  He still tentative on his knee, but he keeps jogging. And then, slowly, the determination melts from his face. jog turns into a walk, and then he just...stops.

Quincy stands in the middle of his room, taking in his li Old, worn basketball posters still line the walls.  Troph and awards.  USC memorabilia.  His basketball globe light He walks to his window, looks out at Monica's window.  He room is dark.

Quincy tilts his face up to the shower head and rinses th soap from his face.  He hears the bathroom door open.  He shuts off the water and opens the curtain. Kyra sits on the toilet, taking a pee.  Quincy slams the curtain closed.
Damn, girl.
What?
I don't wanna see that.
Get used to it, babe. She flushes.  Quincy steps out, grabs a towel.  A long sc runs across his knee cap.
Brother's gonna have to start locking doors. Kyra laughs as she buttons up her flight attendant's unif They cross into:
Kyra packs up a suitcase.
So how long is this trip?
Four days. Quincy nods. KYRA (cont'd)
So are you going to be the kind of husband who won't let his wife work?
Nah.
(playfully)
Why not?
You might be the only one with a job.
Baby, don't talk like that.  Your rehab's going well.  You'll be back before you know it.
Sometimes I wonder if it's worth it. Busting my ass, for what?
To do what you love.
I don't know sometimes.

You're just scared.  I know rehab is hard, and you have to worry about whether you'll be as good as you were but you will be.  I believe in you.  You just have to get back on the court.  Like you'd get back on a horse.
(beat)
A horse?
Don't make fun of me when I'm being wonderful and supportive. (then)
You belong on the court.  Just like I belong in the stands, looking cute and cheering you on. She smiles, gives him a kiss, moves back to her packing. Quincy:
Monica sits at her desk in a blouse and skirt, punching numbers into the computer.  A man sits down in the chair opposite her.  Monica glances up.  It's her father.
Hey, munchkin.
Dad.  What are you doing here?
I was upstairs for a meeting.  I've been hearing good things about you.
That tends to happen when you're the boss's daughter.
So how's the job going? Monica forces a smile.
You know. Nathan looks at her, nods.
I think I know what the problem is. He pulls a GARBAGE CAN HOOP from a plastic shopping bag. Monica smiles.  He attaches it to her garbage can. NATHAN (cont'd)
There. He shoots an ugly, imaginary shot.  She laughs.
You shoot like a girl.
I'll take that as a compliment. He gives her a smile, and exits.  Monica looks at the hoo then crumples a piece of paper.
(whispering)
And she gets the steal.  Monica goes one- on-one against Jordan, she stops, pops... Monica shoots.  The paper drops through the net. MONICA (cont'd) (still whispering)
It's good!  It's good! She glances up, notices a few patrons watching her.  Moni quickly composes herself and goes back to her work.
Monica exits her car, after a long day at work.  She wear very low heels.  But she still stumbles.  She curses, the hears a laugh. She looks up - Quincy sits on the grassy hill above her house.
I remember when your mom had to beat you into a dress. Monica smiles.
You visiting?
(nods)
Kyra's gone for a couple days.  Figured I'd keep Mom company.
Who's this guy I always see her around?
Darryl.  He's alright, kinda corny.
So...how's the knee?
Getting there.
Strong enough to get you down the aisle?
Yeah.  Two weeks. (then)
I didn't get to send you an invitation, but if you...
That's okay.  I'm probably, you know, busy. Quincy nods.  Awkward beat.
Can I ask you something? Monica looks at him. QUINCY (cont'd)
You never told me why ball isn't fun anymore.
It just isn't.
Because I'm kinda feeling that way, too.
You had a rough couple years, that's all.
That a nice way of saying I rode the bench?
And you tore up your knee.  Rehab is tough.
Nah.  I haven't dribbled a ball in four and a half months.  Maybe I miss some of the attention, but besides that...
You're serious.
Seems like I needed a ball when I was trying to be like my pops...or trying to be better than him.  Now, I kinda think I need to try something else.
Like what?
Maybe go back to school.
Wow. Monica stares at him, seeing a man in the boy she grew up with.  Quincy looks away, self-conscious.
I mean, Kyra hasn't heard the school thing yet. (then)
She'll probably say it's the painkillers talking.
It's a trip, you know?  When you're a kid, you see the life you want, and it never crosses your mind that it's not gonna turn out that way.
So why'd you give up ball?
Why do you keep asking me that?
Cause I don't get it.
Something was just missing.
What? Monica is too hurt, too scared to tell him the truth.
It doesn't matter, alright.  Just leave it alone.
Find. Monica turns, crosses to her house.  She stumbles on her heels, kicks them off in frustration, and exits inside. Quincy walks back to his curb.
Camille watches from the kitchen window
Lena sits next to Camille.  Her one year old son, L.P., s on the ground at her feet.  Monica sits quietly nearby, watching.
So you're still breast-feeding?
The doctor said it was okay.  Anyway, I'm still trying to lose some of this baby fat. She quickly looks over at Monica. LENA (cont'd)
Shut up. Monica gives her a small smile.  Camille looks down at L.
You might want to put a jacket on him, it's getting cold.
He's fine.
(warning)
Okay. Lena sighs, rolls her eyes.  She picks up her son.
Come on, L.P.  Grandma says it's too cold. She exits inside.  Camille makes a face.
God.  "Grandma." Monica smiles.  And then silence.  There is still so much distance between them, so many misunderstanding.  Camille stares at her daughter.  And then... CAMILLE (cont'd)
You know, I'd probably be a lot more "prissy" in the situation than you'd like, but the thing I always admired that drove me crazy, was the fight you had in you.
What are you talking about?
When I said Quincy could do better, I was thinking about you. Monica stares at her mom.  Camille stands and leaves.

Monica lies in her bed, staring up at the ceiling, unable sleep.  Her mind races with thoughts of her past, her choices, her future... Suddenly, she climbs out of bed.  She wears a tank-top an pajama bottoms.  She crosses to her window, pulls it open climbs out.
Monica drops down.  She moves to Quincy's window and knoc quietly.  Beat, then Quincy appears.  Bare-chested and in pair of shorts.  He looks at her, then pulls open the win
(half-asleep)
What's going on?
We need to talk. Quincy just looks at her. MONICA (cont'd)
Please.
Hold on. Quincy disappears for a moment, then returns, pulling on shirt.  He climbs out of his window, drops to the ground. Quincy looks at her.
You asked me what was missing.
What?
From basketball.
you woke me up to tell me that?
It's not fun for me anymore because you're missing. Quincy stares at her. MONICA (cont'd)
What I'm trying to say is --
I heard enough.
What I'm trying to say is, I've loved you since I was eleven and the shit won't go away.
We haven't talked since college and now you wait two weeks before my wedding to say something like this?
I know, I probably should have said it two weeks ago. Quincy doesn't even crack a smile.  In fact, he glares.
You haven't changed.  You still think the sun rises and sets on your ass.  Well, guess what, it doesn't.
Then why are you so upset?
Because you don't pull this on someone who's about to get married.
Better late than never, right?
Wrong. Quincy starts back toward the window.
I'll play you.
What?
One game.  One-on-one.
For what?
Your heart. Quincy looks at her in disbelief, then laughs at the absurdity.
You're out of your mind.
So you're gonna bitch up?
What's that supposed to be, psychology?
I know why you broke up with me in college.  And not that what you did wasn't messed up, but what I did was, too.  So if you forgive me, I'll forgive you.

Monica, after that stuff with my dad, I couldn't trust anybody, okay.  I mean, I was lost.  So you are forgiven.  But that was five years ago.  I moved on. Monica moves past him, reaches through his window.  She d back down, holding his basketball.
Prove it. She throws him the ball.
What will this prove?
You once said the reason I beat you was because you wanted me to.
So?
So, if I win it's because deep down you know you're about to make the biggest mistake of your life, and deep down your want me to stop you.
And what happens when you lose?
If I lose, I'll buy you a wedding present. Quincy stares at her.
Monica stands opposite Quincy.  Both are suited up in basketball gear. They stare at each other, ready to go to war. Monica toss him the ball.

Check. Quincy tosses the ball back.  Monica drives.  Quincy's kn is maybe at sixty percent and he can't keep up.  She scor easily. She walks to the top of the driveway, tosses him the ball MONICA (cont'd)

One, zip.  Check. Quincy rubs his scarred knee, then passes it back. The game continues.  Monica owns the first five points ea by exploiting Quincy's injury. Monica drives for another lay-up.  Quincy suddenly lets g his fear, leaps and swats her shot. He grabs the rebound and lays it up.  He nods intensely, he grabs the ball and walks back to the top of the key.

One, five.  Check. The game continues and now Quincy has the upper-hand, usi his size and strength.  He scores seven straight points. The score stays close.  It is a sexually-charged battle o wills -- Quincy pulls off his sweat-soaked shirt.  Their bodies collide as they wrestle for the ball.  Monica yank off her jersey in frustration.  Her ass bumps into his hi as she backs him in.  Her hands slide across his chest as guards him... Finally, the score hits nine, nine.  Monica slowly walks the top of the key.
Nine, up.  Point. She tosses Quincy the ball. MONICA (cont'd)

Check. Quincy tosses the ball back, drops low on defense.  Monic fakes an outside shot and Quincy bites.  Monica drives ar him.  SHE HAS A WIDE-OPEN LAY-UP.  SHE PUTS IT UP..AND IT ROLLS OFF THE RIM.  Monica can't believe it. Quincy grabs the loose ball and clears it.  He stares at Monica as he dribbles in front of her.  She stares back. He breaks for the basket.  Monica stays with him.  He goe up.  Monica jumps, desperately tries to block his shot. Quincy dunks on her, knocking her to the ground.  He lets of the rim, and tumbles to the ground also.  GAME OVER. Silence.  Quincy stares at her.  Monica looks back.  Then
(pointed)
All's fair in love and basketball, right? Monica struggles to fight back her tears as she picks her She slowly walks back toward her house.  And then: QUINCY (cont'd)
Hey. Monica slowly stops, turns. QUINCY (cont'd)

Double or nothing. Monica stares at him, wonders if she heard right.  Quincy limps to his feet, picks up the ball and holds it out to Monica slowly walks back to him.  They stare at each othe No more egos, no more bullshit.  Just love. In the moonlight, on the blacktop, they kiss...
Music is blasting, banners are waving, crowd is screaming Magic Johnson sits in a floor seat, watching the game.  A REPORTER interviews him.
So, Magic, are you contemplating another comeback?
(laughs)

No more comebacks.  Tonight I'm just enjoying being a spectator. Behind him, in a second row seat, a ONE YEAR BLACK GIRL s in a lap, bouncing, watching feet and legs ballin' on the court. Quincy leans down, gives the little girl a kiss, then loo out at the court.  It's the Los Angeles Sparks and the Ne York Liberty.  The WNBA. On the court, the women line up for a free-throw.
Let's go, McCall! Monica, sporting a uniform with Wright-McCall on the back the number thirty-two, looks over.  Quincy takes their daughter's hand and waves it. QUINCY (cont'd)
Go Mommy. Monica smiles back, then steps to the line.  The referee tosses her the ball.  Monica stares at the basket, then bounces the ball twice, licks her lips and shoots.
